title: The Political Ecology of Extractive Industries and Changing Waterscapes in the Andes
abstractText:
The aim of this project is to investigate the role of water in changing lives, livelihoods and landscapes in mining areas of the Andes.

Meeting growing demand for water for mining is a key challenge because natural supplies are limited, most existing resources are in use and some sources are sacred among indigenous people.Tensions have thus arisen over increased access to water by mines.

Rather than regarding water solely as an input to, or as a resource that is negatively impacted by, mining, the key research question is:

  •  how does the control over water for mining bring about changes to people's access to water, their livelihoods and their environments?

This will require examining the ways in which water management is organised, influenced and disputed between different users, such as mines, government bodies, NGOs and communities.

Using predominantly qualitative methods including interviews, focus groups, participant observation and life histories, the research will investigate these issues at the national level in Peru and in three case studies in the arid south of the country where mining is established, recent or under development.

By examining how water is controlled, and in whose interests, the findings are expected to show how Andean lives, livelihoods and landscapes become shaped in particular ways
